title: Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU (CAM-ICU)
description: Monitors delirium in ICU patients through systematic assessment of consciousness level, attention, and organized thinking.

parameters.name: rass_score
parameters.description: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) score. Must be ≥-3 for assessment to continue

parameters.name: acute_onset_fluctuating
parameters.description: Is there acute onset of mental status changes or fluctuating course in the past 24 hours?

parameters.name: attention_errors
parameters.description: Number of errors in attention test (letters test - count errors when patient should squeeze hand for letter A in CASABLANCA)

parameters.name: thinking_errors
parameters.description: Number of errors in organized thinking test (yes/no questions and simple commands)

result.name: cam_icu_assessment
result.description: CAM-ICU delirium assessment with detailed breakdown of each feature

ranges.interpretation: Patient does not meet criteria for delirium. Continue routine monitoring and reassess regularly.
Patient meets criteria for delirium. Implement delirium management protocols and consider underlying causes.

references: Ely EW, Inouye SK, Bernard GR, Gordon S, Francis J, May L, et al. Delirium in mechanically ventilated patients: validity and reliability of the confusion assessment method for the intensive care unit (CAM-ICU). JAMA. 2001 Dec 5;286(21):2703-10. doi: 10.1001/jama.286.21.2703.

Ely EW, Margolin R, Francis J, May L, Truman B, Dittus R, et al. Evaluation of delirium in critically ill patients: validation of the Confusion Assessment Method for the Intensive Care Unit (CAM-ICU). Crit Care Med. 2001 Jul;29(7):1370-9. doi: 10.1097/00003246-200107000-00012.

Devlin JW, Skrobik Y, Gélinas C, Needham DM, Slooter AJ, Pandharipande PP, et al. Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Prevention and Management of Pain, Agitation/Sedation, Delirium, Immobility, and Sleep Disruption in Adult Patients in the ICU. Crit Care Med. 2018 Sep;46(9):e825-e873. doi: 10.1097/CCM.0000000000003299.

Sessler CN, Gosnell MS, Grap MJ, Brophy GM, O'Neal PV, Keane KA, et al. The Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale: validity and reliability in adult intensive care unit patients. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2002 Nov 15;166(10):1338-44. doi: 10.1164/rccm.2107138.
formula: CAM-ICU positive if RASS ≥ -3 AND acute onset/fluctuating course AND >2 attention errors AND (RASS ≠ 0 OR >1 thinking errors)
notes: The CAM-ICU is a validated tool for detecting delirium in critically ill patients
Requires Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) assessment as prerequisite
Patient must have RASS ≥ -3 to be assessed (sufficiently awake to participate)
Letters attention test: recite letters from CASABLANCA, patient squeezes hand for letter A
Organized thinking test includes yes/no questions and simple commands
Sensitivity ~95-100% and specificity ~89-93% for delirium detection
Should be performed by trained healthcare professionals
Reassessment recommended at least once per shift in ICU patients
Part of the PADIS guidelines for ICU patient care
Delirium in ICU patients is associated with increased mortality, longer stays, and cognitive impairment
Early detection allows for prompt implementation of delirium management strategies
The tool can be completed in 1-2 minutes by experienced users
